instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3302: What is 820-3302? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: Imac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.4 ohms short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP12V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hey, I'm working on this board, which measures 0.4 ohms from <SIGNAL>PP12V_G3H</SIGNAL> to ground, measured on pin 4/5/6 of J600 . When i put 12v on <SIGNAL>PP12V_G3H</SIGNAL> i get a little heat on <TRANSISTOR>Q7870</TRANSISTOR>. I removed it, measured again, now the 0.4 ohms is on <SIGNAL>PPBUS12V_S5</SIGNAL>. I put the 12v again on <SIGNAL>PPBUS12V_S5</SIGNAL>, but no luck with warm components.
To make sure none of the lower s5 rails are shorted i disconnected L7710, L7610, L7650. after that i still measure the 0.4 ohms on <SIGNAL>PP12V_S5</SIGNAL>. I've done the same with the mosfets for these circuits, still no change.
Are there any sensible options to continue this? Currently the only thing i can think of is to one by one remove all capacitors related to the <SIGNAL>PP12V_S5</SIGNAL> rail and see when the short disappears. I feel like i'm missing something very obvious.

threads.title: Imac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.4 ohms short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP12V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
at 0.4 Ohm and injecting 12V something must almost catch fire. Suspects are high side FETs. First measure from <SIGNAL>12V_S5</SIGNAL> to all main coils and see if there is one that is 0.4 Ohm or lower. 

<CHIP>U9410</CHIP> and 9610 are also on <SIGNAL>12V_S5</SIGNAL>

threads.title: Imac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.4 ohms short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP12V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I checked <SIGNAL>12V_S5</SIGNAL> to all coils (including the ones for <CHIP>U9410</CHIP> and 9610 this time), but none measure 0.4 ohms. With the highside mosfets i'm assuming you mean <TRANSISTOR>Q7650</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7610</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7710</TRANSISTOR>? If so i will take them off to check.

We use a power supply that limits the current, so i set it to 3A at 12v, but the output voltage will drop to .4v or something, so no risk of fires.

threads.title: Imac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.4 ohms short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP12V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I don't care what voltage you set it too. Crank it up and monitor current draw, this will determine how much is is generated. If you are putting 3A into the board something must heat up or there must be a dead short inside the board.

threads.title: Imac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.4 ohms short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP12V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: We have given up on this one. Replaced the motherboard, and everything is ok again.
